      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<!----></span><br><br>The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <span class="line"><!---->The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <!----></span><br><br>In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<span class="line"><!---->In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<!----></span><br><br>I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<span class="line"><!---->I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<!----></span><br><br>I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<span class="line"><!---->I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<!----></span><br><br>I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<span class="line"><!---->I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<!----></span><br><br>Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>1. Open web browser<span class="line"><!---->1. Open web browser<!----></span><br>2. Launch DevTools (F12)<span class="line"><!---->2. Launch DevTools (F12)<!----></span><br>3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<span class="line"><!---->3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<!----></span><br>4. Ask your wife to log off..<span class="line"><!---->4. Ask your wife to log off..<!----></span><br>5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<span class="line"><!---->5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<!----></span><br>6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<span class="line"><!---->6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<!----></span><br>7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <span class="line"><!---->7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <!----></span><br>8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<span class="line"><!---->8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<!----></span><br><br>Please see attached video.<span class="line"><!---->Please see attached video.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<!----></span><br>I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded
          (was: Security: Google Chrome - how to use as "Key-Logger")
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Restrict-View-SecurityTeam OS-Chrome OS-Linux OS-Mac OS-Windows OS-Lacros Type-Feature

        Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a><br><br>That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<span class="line"><!---->That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue. You already have physical access to the computer and could install a key logger, or read the cookie storage. You could even install a modified browser.<span class="line"><!---->As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue. You already have physical access to the computer and could install a key logger, or read the cookie storage. You could even install a modified browser.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<span class="line"><!---->I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<!----></span>Issue 991290<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=991290" title="Raise the &quot;dangerous flag&quot; warning when the SSLKEYLOGFILE environment variable is set"><!---->Issue 991290<!----></a>) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<span class="line"><!---->) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<!----></span><br><br>Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<span class="line"><!---->Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>
    <mr-click-throughs></mr-click-throughs>

            star_border
          <i class="material-icons" role="presentation">
            star_border
          </i>
        
      <button class="" role="checkbox" title="Login to star this issue." aria-checked="false">
        
          <i class="material-icons" role="presentation">
            star_border

        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<!----></span><br><br>The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <span class="line"><!---->The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <!----></span><br><br>In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<span class="line"><!---->In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<!----></span><br><br>I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<span class="line"><!---->I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<!----></span><br><br>I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<span class="line"><!---->I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<!----></span><br><br>I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<span class="line"><!---->I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<!----></span><br><br>Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>1. Open web browser<span class="line"><!---->1. Open web browser<!----></span><br>2. Launch DevTools (F12)<span class="line"><!---->2. Launch DevTools (F12)<!----></span><br>3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<span class="line"><!---->3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<!----></span><br>4. Ask your wife to log off..<span class="line"><!---->4. Ask your wife to log off..<!----></span><br>5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<span class="line"><!---->5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<!----></span><br>6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<span class="line"><!---->6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<!----></span><br>7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <span class="line"><!---->7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <!----></span><br>8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<span class="line"><!---->8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<!----></span><br><br>Please see attached video.<span class="line"><!---->Please see attached video.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<!----></span><br>I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Summary:<strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded

          <br>

      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded
          (was: Security: Google Chrome - how to use as "Key-Logger")
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Restrict-View-SecurityTeam OS-Chrome OS-Linux OS-Mac OS-Windows OS-Lacros Type-Feature
          
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Components:</strong>
          
          Internals&gt;Network&gt;Logging Platform&gt;DevTools&gt;Network Platform&gt;DevTools&gt;UX
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a><br><br>That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<span class="line"><!---->That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue. You already have physical access to the computer and could install a key logger, or read the cookie storage.         by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<span class="line"><!---->I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<!----></span>Issue 991290<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=991290" title="Raise the &quot;dangerous flag&quot; warning when the SSLKEYLOGFILE environment variable is set"><!---->Issue 991290<!----></a>) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<span class="line"><!---->) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<!----></span><br><br>Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<span class="line"><!---->Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        NetLog is how we ask end users to collect information to debug network-related issues.  It's not solely targeted at Chrome devs (and is not at all targeted at web devs, though they may find it useful for debugging certain network-layer issues)<span class="line"><!---->NetLog is how we ask end users to collect information to debug network-related issues.  It's not solely targeted at Chrome devs (and is not at all targeted at web devs, though they may find it useful for debugging certain network-layer issues)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        mr-issue-details {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background-color: var(--chops-white);
          padding-bottom: 1em;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          flex-direction: column;
          margin: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
        }
        h3 {
          margin-top: 1em;
        }
        mr-description {
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        mr-edit-issue {
          margin-top: 40px;
        }
      <style>
        mr-issue-details {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background-color: var(--chops-white);

          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;

        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<!----></span><br><br>The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <span class="line"><!---->The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <!----></span><br><br>In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<span class="line"><!---->In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<!----></span><br><br>I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<span class="line"><!---->I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<!----></span><br><br>I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<span class="line"><!---->I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<!----></span><br><br>I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<span class="line"><!---->I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<!----></span><br><br>Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>1. Open web browser<span class="line"><!---->1. Open web browser<!----></span><br>2. Launch DevTools (F12)<span class="line"><!---->2. Launch DevTools (F12)<!----></span><br>3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<span class="line"><!---->3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<!----></span><br>4. Ask your wife to log off..<span class="line"><!---->4. Ask your wife to log off..<!----></span><br>5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<span class="line"><!---->5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<!----></span><br>6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<span class="line"><!---->6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<!----></span><br>7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <span class="line"><!---->7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <!----></span><br>8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<span class="line"><!---->8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<!----></span><br><br>Please see attached video.<span class="line"><!---->Please see attached video.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<!----></span><br>I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded
          (was: Security: Google Chrome - how to use as "Key-Logger")
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>

        Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a><br><br>That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<span class="line"><!---->That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        Thanks for letting us know -- you can feel free to blog about this. This bug is also publicly visible now so you can refer to it if you'd like.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for letting us know -- you can feel free to blog about this. This bug is also publicly visible now so you can refer to it if you'd like.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue. You already have physical access to the computer and could install a key logger, or read the cookie storage. You could even install a modified browser.<span class="line"><!---->As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue.           <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1450231#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<span class="line"><!---->I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<!----></span>Issue 991290<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=991290" title="Raise the &quot;dangerous flag&quot; warning when the SSLKEYLOGFILE environment variable is set"><!---->Issue 991290<!----></a>) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<span class="line"><!---->) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<!----></span><br><br>Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<span class="line"><!---->Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

      This issue has been migrated to Launch, see link in final comment below.<p>This issue has been migrated to Launch, see link in final comment below.</p>

        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by artur...@gmail.com (May 31, 2023)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<!----></span><br><br>The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <span class="line"><!---->The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <!----></span><br><br>In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<span class="line"><!---->In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<!----></span><br><br>I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<span class="line"><!---->I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<!----></span><br><br>I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<span class="line"><!---->I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<!----></span><br><br>I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<span class="line"><!---->I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<!----></span><br><br>Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>1. Open web browser<span class="line"><!---->1. Open web browser<!----></span><br>2. Launch DevTools (F12)<span class="line"><!---->2. Launch DevTools (F12)<!----></span><br>3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<span class="line"><!---->3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<!----></span><br>4. Ask your wife to log off..<span class="line"><!---->4. Ask your wife to log off..<!----></span><br>5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<span class="line"><!---->5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<!----></span><br>6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<span class="line"><!---->6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<!----></span><br>7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <span class="line"><!---->7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <!----></span><br>8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<span class="line"><!---->8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<!----></span><br><br>Please see attached video.<span class="line"><!---->Please see attached video.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<!----></span><br>I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded
          (was: Security: Google Chrome - how to use as "Key-Logger")
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Restrict-View-SecurityTeam OS-Chrome OS-Linux OS-Mac OS-Windows OS-Lacros Type-Feature
          
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Components:</strong>
          
          Internals&gt;Network&gt;Logging Platform&gt;DevTools&gt;Network Platform&gt;DevTools&gt;UX
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a><br><br>That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<span class="line"><!---->That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<span class="line"><!---->I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<!----></span>Issue 991290<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=991290" title="Raise the &quot;dangerous flag&quot; warning when the SSLKEYLOGFILE environment variable is set"><!---->Issue 991290<!----></a>) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<span class="line"><!---->) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<!----></span><br><br>Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<span class="line"><!---->Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<!----></span><br><br>The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <span class="line"><!---->The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <!----></span><br><br>In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<span class="line"><!---->In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<!----></span><br><br>I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<span class="line"><!---->I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<!----></span><br><br>I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<span class="line"><!---->I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<!----></span><br><br>I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<span class="line"><!---->I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<!----></span><br><br>Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>1. Open web browser<span class="line"><!---->1. Open web browser<!----></span><br>2. Launch DevTools (F12)<span class="line"><!---->2. Launch DevTools (F12)<!----></span><br>3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<span class="line"><!---->3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<!----></span><br>4. Ask your wife to log off..<span class="line"><!---->4. Ask your wife to log off..<!----></span><br>5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<span class="line"><!---->5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<!----></span><br>6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<span class="line"><!---->6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<!----></span><br>7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <span class="line"><!---->7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <!----></span><br>8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<span class="line"><!---->8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<!----></span><br><br>Please see attached video.<span class="line"><!---->Please see attached video.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes.       <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded
          (was: Security: Google Chrome - how to use as "Key-Logger")
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Restrict-View-SecurityTeam OS-Chrome OS-Linux OS-Mac OS-Windows OS-Lacros Type-Feature
          
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Components:</strong>
          
          Internals&gt;Network&gt;Logging Platform&gt;DevTools&gt;Network Platform&gt;DevTools&gt;UX
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your report. As you mention, the ability to record a NetLog in Chrome is working-as-intended. We don't consider local attackers in-scope for Chrome's threat model, as there are many things that someone with full access to the machine (and user account) can already do to subvert a user's privacy and security that are difficult or impossible for Chrome to protect against on legacy platforms (unlike on Android/iOS with full separation of principals). See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/main/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a><br><br>That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<span class="line"><!---->That said, it may be worth considering if we should treat "net log recording in progress" similarly to "debugger extension is active" for users and show some persistent infobar or other indicator of this fact, so this seems like a reasonable security-adjacent feature request. Updating the title accordingly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue. You already have physical access to the computer and could install a key logger, or read the cookie storage. You could even install a modified browser.<span class="line"><!---->As mentioned above, I also don't think this is a security issue. You already have physical access to the computer and could install a key logger, or read the cookie storage.         by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1450231#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1450231#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Jun 14, 2023, 12:06 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<span class="line"><!---->I do think this is worth considering as a feature request (it just isn't a security bug) as we include other warnings to users about uncommon configurations (such as the Dangerous Flags Infobar for things like `--disable-sandbox`). That said, this seems conceptually most similar to the SSLKEYLOGFILE flag, which we previously tried to add to the dangerous flags infobar (<!----></span>Issue 991290<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=991290" title="Raise the &quot;dangerous flag&quot; warning when the SSLKEYLOGFILE environment variable is set"><!---->Issue 991290<!----></a>) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<span class="line"><!---->) but had to revert due to security software using it and causing problems. We do want to revisit that in the future potentially though.<!----></span><br><br>Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<span class="line"><!---->Installing root software often requires a knowledge factor (account password) that makes local abuse harder depending on configuration. Maybe this is another argument for having an opt-in Developer Mode to make it harder to use for local abuse?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        NetLog is how we ask end users to collect information to debug network-related issues.  It's not solely targeted at Chrome devs (and is not at all targeted at web devs, though they may find it useful for debugging certain network-layer issues)<span class="line"><!---->NetLog is how we ask end users to collect information to debug network-related issues.  It's not solely targeted at Chrome devs (and is not at all targeted at web devs, though they may find it useful for debugging certain network-layer issues)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to report the existence of a “hidden” functionality in the Google Chrome browser that may pose a potential threat to computer users. I have discovered that the developer tools available in the browser, particularly the Network tab, allow for the interception of data entered via the keyboard, including usernames and passwords.<!----></span><br><br>The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <span class="line"><!---->The problem lies in the fact that the majority of websites do not encrypt such data during input (payload), but only during transmission using SSL/TLS encryption protocols. As a result, after logging into a website, login credentials such as usernames and passwords are visible in plain text within the Network tab of the developer tools as "payload". Additionally, these tools have a recording feature that saves all browsing-related events to a file. <!----></span><br><br>In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<span class="line"><!---->In practice, this means that if multiple individuals use the same computer or account, it is possible to intercept all entered data, including sensitive login information. Furthermore, this method goes undetected by any antivirus tools or any cybersecurity tools.<!----></span><br><br>I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<span class="line"><!---->I am deeply concerned about this discovery, as the "key-logger" functionality could be exploited unethically, compromising user privacy and security. Given that the Google Chrome browser is widely used, there is a potential risk for users worldwide.<!----></span><br><br>I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<span class="line"><!---->I kindly request that you take immediate action to address this significant security issue concerning users of the Google Chrome browser. We need changes and additional safeguards to help minimize the risk of developer tools being used as a "keylogger" and to protect the personal data and sensitive information of users.<!----></span><br><br>I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<span class="line"><!---->I am confident that your company will take appropriate actions to address this issue and provide users of the Google Chrome browser with a secure and confidential internet browsing environment.<!----></span><br><br>Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for your attention and understanding. I look forward to your actions on this matter and to receiving feedback regarding the steps taken to improve the security of the Google Chrome browser.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 114.0.5735.91 (public)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3031)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>1. Open web browser<span class="line"><!---->1. Open web browser<!----></span><br>2. Launch DevTools (F12)<span class="line"><!---->2. Launch DevTools (F12)<!----></span><br>3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<span class="line"><!---->3. Ask your wife to login somewhere…<!----></span><br>4. Ask your wife to log off..<span class="line"><!---->4. Ask your wife to log off..<!----></span><br>5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<span class="line"><!---->5. Export data in Dev Tools to HAR file.<!----></span><br>6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<span class="line"><!---->6. Review HAR file to find sensitive data (user name/password etc.)<!----></span><br>7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <span class="line"><!---->7. Logon to the same service using your wife credentials <!----></span><br>8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<span class="line"><!---->8. Wait for your wife frustration 😉<!----></span><br><br>Please see attached video.<span class="line"><!---->Please see attached video.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Artur Ogloza - SIX<!----></span><br>I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<span class="line"><!---->I would like to ask for bug bounty for this specific finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Summary:<strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          Not obvious when NetLog is being recorded
          (was: Security: Google Chrome - how to use as "Key-Logger")
          <br>
        
          Labels:<strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
